media:group.media:title: Bubble pipe optimization
media:group.media:description:
Bubbles travel through a pipe in two dimensions. The shape of the pipe is optimized using three different objectives: less coalescence, more coalescence, and faster transport.
Supplementary video to article https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cma.2021.114264 Simulation in Aphros https://github.com/cselab/aphros Optimization in Korali https://github.com/cselab/korali

entry.title: Fluid flow past a Christmas tree

media:group.media:title: Fluid flow past a Christmas tree
media:group.media:description: Simulation in Aphros https://github.com/cselab/aphros Color shows the vorticity field (red for counterclockwise and blue for clockwise).

entry.title: Coupling of Aphros and LAMMPS: polymers in Taylor-Green vortex

media:group.media:title: Coupling of Aphros and LAMMPS: polymers in Taylor-Green vortex
media:group.media:description: Demonstration of coupling between the fluid flow solver Aphros https://github.com/cselab/aphros and molecular dynamics solver LAMMPS. The force acting on the polymers is computed from the velocity field of the liquid. Simulation by Sergey Litvinov.

media:group.media:title: Bubbles penetrating a solid mesh
media:group.media:description: Bubbles in a force field penetrate a solid mesh. Simulation in Aphros https://github.com/cselab/aphros

entry.title: Air entrainment by a plunging jet

media:group.media:title: Air entrainment by a plunging jet
media:group.media:description:
A water jet captures air and generates bubbles.
Simulation in Aphros https://github.com/cselab/aphros
Supplementary movie to article A High Performance Computing Framework for Multiphase, Turbulent Flows on Structured Grids https://doi.org/10.1145/3324989.3325727

media:group.media:title: Taylor-Green vortex with bubbles
media:group.media:description: Supplementary movie to article A High Performance Computing Framework for Multiphase, Turbulent Flows on Structured Grids https://doi.org/10.1145/3324989.3325727

media:group.media:title: Bubble trapped by vortex ring
media:group.media:description: Supplementary movie to article Bubbles in turbulent flows: Data-driven, kinematic models with history terms https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijmultiphaseflow.2020.103286

media:group.media:title: Bubble jump-off in electrochemical reactor
media:group.media:description:
Supplementary movie to article A versatile and membrane-less electrochemical reactor for the electrolysis of water and brine https://doi.org/10.1039/C9EE00219G
Hydrogen and oxygen bubbles forming on the electrodes coalesce and jump away from the electrodes. Experimental results overlayed by contour from simulation (red lines). Simulation done in Aphros https://github.com/cselab/aphros

entry.title: Merging bubbles create a satellite while droplets do not

media:group.media:title: Merging bubbles create a satellite while droplets do not
media:group.media:description: Compare coalescence of bubbles (left) and droplets (right) in this vertical arrangement. Bubbles create a small satellite bubble while droplets do not. The initial radius of bubbles and droplets is 0.5 mm. The video is slowed down and covers 5 milliseconds of physical time. Simulation done with Aphros https://github.com/cselab/aphros . Results on satellite formation agree with experiment https://doi.org/10.1063/1.2835664 . Checkout the gallery of interactive simulations https://github.com/cselab/aphros/wiki/Aphros-Explorer

media:group.media:title: Bubbling oscillator with microfluidic crystals
media:group.media:description: Bubbles in this microfluidic device closely pack and form crystalline structures. Differences in dissipation cause spontaneous transitions between two states. Simulation done in Aphros https://github.com/cselab/aphros . See article https://arxiv.org/abs/2103.01513 for details and more applications.

media:group.media:title: Rising bubbles float in water
media:group.media:description: Bubbles are generated at the bottom of a water tank. They rise to the surface and form clusters. The clustering is known as the Cheerios effect for the similarity to breakfast cereals in milk. Simulation done with Aphros https://github.com/cselab/aphros See article (https://arxiv.org/abs/2103.01513â€‹) for more applications and details. Check out online demos: - liquid drops and coalescence prevention https://cselab.github.io/aphros/wasm/hydro.html - electrochemical reactor https://cselab.github.io/aphros/wasm/electrochem.html

entry.title: Passive generation of bidisperse foam with microbubbles

media:group.media:title: Passive generation of bidisperse foam with microbubbles
media:group.media:description: This microfluidic device generates bidisperse foam by splitting every second bubble. The alternation is based on a slight change in the distance between the "pincher" bubble and the "wall" bubble downstream. Simulation done in Aphros https://github.com/cselab/aphros . See article https://arxiv.org/abs/2103.01513 for more applications and details. Check out the gallery of interactive fluid simulations https://github.com/cselab/aphros/wiki/Aphros-Explorer

media:group.media:title: Foaming waterfall
media:group.media:description: Foam created by waterfall in soapy water. Simulation done with Aphros (https://github.com/cselab/aphros). Took 20 hours on 14000 cores of the Piz Daint supercomputer. Details and more applications in article (https://arxiv.org/abs/2103.01513) Check out online demos: - liquid drops and coalescence prevention https://cselab.github.io/aphros/wasm/hydro.html - electrochemical reactor https://cselab.github.io/aphros/wasm/electrochem.html

entry.title: Coalescence of underwater bubbles in slow motion

media:group.media:title: Coalescence of underwater bubbles in slow motion
media:group.media:description: This is how the merging of two bubbles would look on a high speed camera. Parameters correspond to bubbles of a radius of 0.3 mm. Simulation done with Aphros https://github.com/cselab/aphros . Results are experimentally validated https://arxiv.org/pdf/1906.00314.pdf#subsection.A.2 . Check out the gallery of interactive fluid simulations https://github.com/cselab/aphros/wiki/Aphros-Explorer

media:group.media:title: Sound of droplets
media:group.media:description: A shockwave passes through water droplets. This is how it sounds.
